metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Describe the interaction of two fields, allowing that electric charges, magnetic poles and current carrying conductors can either attract or repel, whereas masses only attract each other

like_charges_repel.name: Like Charges Repel
like_charges_repel.correct: Two positive charges repel each other. Two negative charges also repel each other. Like charges always experience a repulsive force.

attract.error: You've confused the rule. Like charges repel, not attract.
attract.fix: Think about static electricity: rub a balloon and it repels another charged balloon of the same type.
attract.action: Memorise: like repels, opposite attracts. Test yourself with + + and − − pairs.

have no interaction.error: Charges always interact when within range of each other's electric field.
have no interaction.fix: Any two charges will exert forces on each other. The question is whether the force is attractive or repulsive.
have no interaction.action: Draw field lines between two positive charges. Note they diverge, indicating repulsion.

sometimes attract, sometimes repel.error: The behaviour is deterministic, not random.
sometimes attract, sometimes repel.fix: For charges of the same sign, the interaction is always repulsion. No exceptions.
sometimes attract, sometimes repel.action: Consider why: field lines point away from positive. Two positives push each other away.

persistent.gap: You're not reliably distinguishing charge interactions.
persistent.action: Create a table: (+,+) → repel, (−,−) → repel, (+,−) → attract. Drill until automatic.

opposite_charges_attract.name: Opposite Charges Attract
opposite_charges_attract.correct: A positive charge and a negative charge attract each other. The electric force pulls them together.

repel.error: Opposite charges attract, they don't repel.
repel.fix: Field lines from + point toward −. This means the force pulls them together.
repel.action: Visualise: electron orbits proton because opposite charges attract.

have no interaction.fix: The attraction between opposite charges is the basis of atomic structure.
have no interaction.action: Consider: what holds electrons in atoms? Attraction to the positive nucleus.

cancel out.error: Charges don't cancel. They exert forces on each other.
cancel out.fix: The forces are attractive. The charges remain distinct objects that pull toward each other.
cancel out.action: Cancellation refers to net charge, not forces. Two charges still exert forces on each other.

persistent.gap: You're confusing charge interaction with charge cancellation.
persistent.action: Distinguish clearly: force interaction (attract/repel) vs net charge calculation (add/subtract).

like_poles_repel.name: Like Magnetic Poles Repel
like_poles_repel.correct: Two north poles repel each other. Two south poles also repel each other. Like magnetic poles always repel.

attract.fix: Just like charges: similar types push away from each other.
attract.action: Try it with two magnets. Put two north poles together and feel the push.

have no interaction.error: Magnetic poles always interact when in range.
have no interaction.fix: Magnets exert forces on each other. The question is the direction of that force.
have no interaction.action: Hold two magnets near each other. You'll feel a force, either push or pull.

pass through each other.error: Magnetic fields don't make physical objects pass through each other.
pass through each other.fix: The poles experience a repulsive force. They push apart, not through.
pass through each other.action: Magnetic repulsion is a real force. It's used in maglev trains.

persistent.gap: You're not applying pole interaction rules correctly.
persistent.action: Memorise: like repels (N-N, S-S), unlike attracts (N-S). Same as charges.

opposite_poles_attract.name: Opposite Magnetic Poles Attract
opposite_poles_attract.correct: A north pole and a south pole attract each other. This is why magnets stick together in certain orientations.

repel.error: Opposite poles attract, they don't repel.
repel.fix: Field lines go from N to S. The poles are pulled together along these lines.
repel.action: Put the N of one magnet near the S of another. They snap together.

have no interaction.fix: The attraction is why magnets stick to your fridge.
have no interaction.action: Experiment: opposite poles attract so strongly they're hard to pull apart.

merge into one pole.error: Poles don't merge. They attract but remain distinct.
merge into one pole.fix: Bringing N and S together creates a stronger combined magnet, but both poles still exist.
merge into one pole.action: Even when magnets touch, each keeps its own poles. They don't fuse.

persistent.action: Handle actual magnets. Feel the attraction between N and S. It's unmistakable.

magnetic_dipoles_only.name: Magnets Only Exist as Dipoles
magnetic_dipoles_only.formula: Every magnet has N and S
magnetic_dipoles_only.correct: Magnetic monopoles have never been found. Every magnet has both a north pole and a south pole. Cut a magnet in half and you get two smaller dipoles.

can be isolated.fix: Unlike electric charges, you cannot have a north pole without a south pole.
can be isolated.action: Try cutting a magnet. Each piece has both N and S. You can't get just one.

exist in nature.error: Despite theoretical predictions, no magnetic monopole has ever been detected.
exist in nature.fix: Physicists have searched for decades. Magnets are always dipoles.
exist in nature.action: This is a fundamental difference: electric monopoles exist, magnetic monopoles don't.

are created by breaking magnets.error: Breaking a magnet doesn't create monopoles.
are created by breaking magnets.fix: Breaking creates two smaller dipoles, each with its own N and S.
are created by breaking magnets.action: Each fragment is a complete magnet. No matter how small, it has both poles.

persistent.gap: You believe magnetic monopoles can exist.
persistent.action: Key fact: electric charges come in single units, magnetic poles always come in pairs.

parallel_conductors_same_direction.name: Parallel Currents Attract
parallel_conductors_same_direction.correct: Two parallel wires carrying current in the same direction attract each other. Each wire's magnetic field exerts a force on the other wire.

repel.error: Same direction parallel currents attract, not repel.
repel.fix: Use the right-hand rules: each wire's field causes an inward force on the other.
repel.action: Apply right-hand grip to find B from wire 1, then right-hand slap for force on wire 2.

have no interaction.error: Current-carrying wires create magnetic fields and interact.
have no interaction.fix: The magnetic field from one wire exerts a force on the current in the other wire.
have no interaction.action: This interaction defines the ampere unit. It's fundamental to electromagnetism.

twist around each other.error: The force is attractive, pulling the wires closer, not twisting them.
twist around each other.fix: The force acts perpendicular to both wires, pulling them together.
twist around each other.action: The wires would move closer together, not rotate.

persistent.gap: You can't determine the force direction between parallel currents.
persistent.action: Step by step: (1) field from wire A at wire B, (2) force on wire B using F = BIL direction.

parallel_conductors_opposite_direction.name: Antiparallel Currents Repel
parallel_conductors_opposite_direction.correct: Two parallel wires carrying current in opposite directions repel each other. The magnetic interaction pushes them apart.

attract.error: Opposite direction currents repel, not attract.
attract.fix: When currents flow opposite ways, the right-hand rules show outward forces.
attract.action: Carefully trace: B-field direction from each wire, then force on the other.

have no interaction.fix: The magnetic force between wires depends on current direction, but it's never zero.
have no interaction.action: The force exists regardless of direction. Direction determines attract vs repel.

create a stronger magnetic field.error: The question is about the force between the wires, not field strength.
create a stronger magnetic field.fix: The wires repel each other. Field strength is a separate consideration.
create a stronger magnetic field.action: Focus on the force direction: opposite currents → repulsion between wires.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly applying magnetic force rules to conductors.
persistent.action: Practice: draw two wires, assign currents, find B, find F. Do 10 examples.

gravity_only_attracts.name: Gravity Only Attracts
gravity_only_attracts.correct: Gravitational fields can only produce attraction. There is no negative mass, so there is no gravitational repulsion.

can repel.error: Gravity never repels. It always attracts.
can repel.fix: Unlike charges or poles, mass only comes in one 'type'. All masses attract all other masses.
can repel.action: No matter what two objects you choose, gravity pulls them together.

can attract or repel depending on mass.error: The magnitude of mass affects force strength, not direction.
can attract or repel depending on mass.fix: More mass means stronger attraction. But it's always attraction, never repulsion.
can attract or repel depending on mass.action: Gravity's direction is always toward the other mass. Always.

has no effect at small scales.error: Gravity exists at all scales, just very weak at small scales.
has no effect at small scales.fix: Gravity is always attractive. It's just overwhelmed by other forces at atomic scales.
has no effect at small scales.action: Electric forces dominate atoms, but gravity is still there, pulling.

persistent.gap: You think gravity can repel under some conditions.
persistent.action: Fundamental fact: gravity = attraction only. No exceptions in classical physics.

no_negative_mass.name: No Negative Mass Exists
no_negative_mass.correct: Unlike electric charge, which can be positive or negative, mass only comes in positive values. This is why gravity only attracts.

negative mass exists but is rare.error: Negative mass has never been observed.
negative mass exists but is rare.fix: All matter has positive mass. There's no 'antimass' like there's antimatter.
negative mass exists but is rare.action: Note: antimatter has positive mass. Positrons have the same mass as electrons.

antimatter has negative mass.error: Common misconception. Antimatter has positive mass.
antimatter has negative mass.fix: A positron has the same mass as an electron. Only charge is opposite.
antimatter has negative mass.action: Antimatter annihilates with matter because of opposite charge, not mass.

dark matter is negative mass.error: Dark matter has positive mass. That's why it gravitationally attracts.
dark matter is negative mass.fix: Dark matter is detected by its gravitational attraction. Negative mass would repel.
dark matter is negative mass.action: Galaxy rotation curves show dark matter pulls inward, confirming positive mass.

persistent.gap: You believe some form of negative mass exists.
persistent.action: Accept: all observed mass is positive. This explains why gravity only attracts.

field_interaction_comparison.name: Comparing Field Interactions
field_interaction_comparison.formula: Electric/Magnetic: attract or repel; Gravity: attract only
field_interaction_comparison.correct: Electric charges and magnetic poles can either attract or repel depending on their type. Masses can only attract each other.

all fields only attract.error: Only gravity exclusively attracts. Electric and magnetic can repel.
all fields only attract.fix: Like charges repel, like poles repel. Gravity has no equivalent repulsion.
all fields only attract.action: Key difference: + and − exist for charge; N and S for magnets; only + for mass.

all fields can attract and repel.error: Gravity cannot repel. It only attracts.
all fields can attract and repel.fix: Gravity is the odd one out. No gravitational repulsion exists.
all fields can attract and repel.action: This is the main point of this dot point: gravity is unique in being attraction-only.

magnetic fields only attract.error: Like magnetic poles repel each other.
magnetic fields only attract.fix: N-N repels, S-S repels, N-S attracts. Just like charges.
magnetic fields only attract.action: Try pushing two north poles together. You'll feel the repulsion.

persistent.gap: You're not distinguishing which fields can repel.
persistent.action: Create comparison: Electric (attract/repel), Magnetic (attract/repel), Gravity (attract only).

monopole_existence.name: Monopole Existence by Field Type
monopole_existence.formula: Electric: yes; Magnetic: no; Gravity: yes
monopole_existence.correct: Electric monopoles (single charges) exist. Gravitational monopoles (single masses) exist. Magnetic monopoles (isolated N or S) have never been found.

magnetic monopoles exist.error: Despite decades of searching, no magnetic monopole has been found.
magnetic monopoles exist.fix: Every magnet has both N and S. You cannot isolate one pole.
magnetic monopoles exist.action: This is physics fact: monopoles exist for charge and mass, but not for magnetism.

no monopoles exist.error: Electric and gravitational monopoles definitely exist.
no monopoles exist.fix: A single electron is an electric monopole. A single mass is a gravitational monopole.
no monopoles exist.action: The word 'monopole' means 'single pole'. A proton is a positive electric monopole.

gravitational monopoles don't exist.error: Any single mass is a gravitational monopole.
gravitational monopoles don't exist.fix: Unlike magnets, masses don't come in pairs. Each mass is its own monopole.
gravitational monopoles don't exist.action: Earth is a gravitational monopole. The Moon is another. Each exists independently.

persistent.gap: You're confusing which field types have monopoles.
persistent.action: Table: Electric (monopole exists), Magnetic (only dipoles), Gravity (monopole exists).

current_creates_magnetic_field.name: Current Creates Magnetic Field
current_creates_magnetic_field.correct: A current-carrying conductor creates a magnetic field around it. This field can interact with other magnetic fields or other currents.

creates an electric field.error: Moving charges create magnetic fields, not additional electric fields.
creates an electric field.fix: Static charges create electric fields. Moving charges (current) create magnetic fields.
creates an electric field.action: Oersted discovered this: a compass needle deflects near a current-carrying wire.

creates a gravitational field.error: Current creates magnetic fields, not gravitational fields.
creates a gravitational field.fix: Mass creates gravitational fields. Current (moving charge) creates magnetic fields.
creates a gravitational field.action: Different sources create different fields. Current → magnetic.

has no effect on surroundings.error: Current-carrying conductors definitely affect their surroundings.
has no effect on surroundings.fix: The magnetic field from a wire can deflect compasses, attract/repel other wires.
has no effect on surroundings.action: This is the basis of electromagnets, motors, and generators.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the source of magnetic fields from currents.
persistent.action: Key relationship: stationary charge → E-field only; moving charge → B-field too.
